Posts.Content: Another, Yes,that's the one. VolumeII. It is 11 years old and sampled 379 men. The Sloan Kettering prediction tool is 2015 and used 2254 men from a slightly newer time period. Six times more men should blend out averages. Still, there are completely different predictions from the two.
Posts.Title: Insights and opinions John Hopkins Discovery article

Posts.Content: Gentlemen, Does anyone have a opinion/insight on the article titled "If Prostate Cancer comes Back, Who needs Aggressive Treatment"? The statistical information shows up in several internet web sites, but is easiest to understand there. It utilizes PSA doubling time, Gleason score, and time from surgery to return of PSA as the basis of the observations. It is completely different than the Prediction Tool of the Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Both of these facilities are high on the list of quality care hospitals. How can they be so divergent? Thanks for your thoughts. Jim
Posts.Title: Insights and opinions John Hopkins Discovery article

Posts.Content: Sam, Great story and I hope you and Annabelle continue a good long time. The world needs all the bright side hope that it can find. Jim
Posts.Title: Hypofractionated Radiation

Posts.Content: Gentlemen, Does any one have experience with the shorter salvage radiation therapy? It's 27 sessions rather than 39 with a higher dose of radiation each time. Over all, less total radiation is administered. Any thoughts or suggestions?
Posts.Title: Hypofractionated Radiation

Posts.Content: Thanks Mr. Walking I had not seen that site information. And Merry Christmas, I read your bio. Jim
Posts.Title: Hypofractionated Radiation

Posts.Content: Gentlemen, Yale is part of a study trial called Hypofractionated Post Prostatectomy Therapy. There have been a few trials at different places already that appear to cause less toxicity. The pattern of fewer sessions with higher doses each time has been used for women's breast cancer. Overall, the total radiation strength is reduced. I was wondering if anyone on this board had participated or had any first hand information.
Posts.Title: Hypofractionated Radiation

Posts.Content: Gentlemen, Highlander suggested I put this up for review. I have run the Sloan Kettering"Risk of dying of prostate cancer in men with a rising PSA after radical prostatectomy" nomogram. Basically, PSA 3.8 before surgery, G3+4, 65 years at surgery and now 72,PSA .238 at recurrence, 17.7 months doubling time, and 81 months from surgery to recurrence. Cancer contained to prostate. No further therapy. With that inputed, the SK nomogram suggests I have a 99% chance of dying in 5 years from prostate cancer. Inputing arbitrarily 1 month to recurrence rather than the 81, it suggests a 2% chance dying in 5 years and only 12% in 15 years. Something seems backwards to me. Has anyone else come across this? Thanks for your thoughts! Jim
Posts.Title: Sloan Kettering nomogram question

Posts.Content: Gentlemen, Thanks all for considering my question. 04/27/2010 DaVinci at Yale with 3.8 PSA pre operation PSA < .008 until 12/06/2013 12/06/2013 .044 PSA 06/04 2014 .057 12/05/2014 .079 06/04/2015 .112 11/11/2015 .115 05/31/2016 .151 01/31/2017 .238 07/24/2017 .287 No hormone therapy, no extraprostatic extension, surgical margins clear, no seminal vesicles cancer, no lymph node cancer My urologist has suggested that if I was 10 years younger, there would be no question but to do salvage radiation. The radiation oncologist I spoke to suggested a 60% chance of success. My 7 year older brother has done this with the radiation only setting back his PSA 6 months with complications. So, we all would like to get to our use by date without something like this intervening. I'm just looking for qualified, informed, information as to the future possibilities. Johns Hopkins and Stephen Freedland suggests a 94% chance of going 15 years with my stats. I still don't understand Sloan Kettering's offering. Thanks for your thoughts. Third rock from the Sun Jim
Posts.Title: Sloan Kettering nomogram question

Posts.Content: Gentlemen, Does any one know a approximate cost for Medicare approved salvage radiation, bone scan and cat scans? I understand Medicare pays 80% and the patient pays 20%. I have not heard from Yale yet, or found much on the internet. Thanks for your input.
Posts.Title: Radiation therapy costs

Posts.Content: Gentlemen, This is a remarkable source of information I had not come across before. I had my Prostate out 4/5/10 with the DaVinci system. Ps after was .008 until 12/6/13 when it increased to .044. Then .057,.079,.112,.115,.151,and finally .238 at 6 month intervals. I have a appointment to see a radiation physician this month, but I am a little apprehensive. I'm 71 and in fair health other than the prostate glitch. My older brother went through this same program about 8 years ago and had some unfortunate side effects to the radiation. It also only temporarily set back his psa increase. So, given I'm 71, is the possible trade off of side effects vs possible inhibited psa worth the program? If I was younger, I'm told this would not be a difficult decision. Thanks for your opinion. Again, this is a remarkable site. My meter was leaning more towards the pessimistic side but not any more. Thanks guys My Gleason was 3+4=7 PSA before prostatectomy 3.8 perineural invasion identified carcinoma confined to the prostate lymph nodes clear pT2c Organ confined, bilateral disease
Posts.Title: New Guy with salvage radiation questions

Posts.Content: I completed a 25 session hypo fractionated salvage radiation trial last month. My radiation oncologist told me if the therapy was successful, the PSA should spiral down over 1 to 2 years. Your husbands sounds great and going in the right direction.Best of luck Jim
Posts.Title: Radiation PSA

Posts.Content: I haven't posted in a while but I just wanted to express my appreciation to the Yale Radiation group.In February I entered a salvage radiation non-inferiority hypo fractionation study being run at Yale. I was assigned to the shorter 25 session program. My PSA was .335 at the beginning, .263 at the end and .030 at a 6 month review. I can't say enough about the care and attention by the entire staff at Yale. I have read many difficult posts on this forum so I thought I would add one on the bright side.
Posts.Title: Appreciation to Yale Radiation
